comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: The brass plaque to the left of the door says "Albertina Rasch Dance Studio". Rasch (1891 - 1967) was a dancer and choreographer, based in New York. She was also married to the composer Dmitri Tiomkin. This and the four unidentified room photos that precede it are identified on an Historical Ziegfeld site as being of Rasch's dance studio. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albertina_Rasch historicalziegfeld.multiply.com/photos/album/297# From a biographical sketch on the official Dmitri Tomkin website, comes the following: "Eager to impart her experience and knowledge to teachers, other dancers, and children, she settled in New York and opened the Albertina Rasch Dance Studio in October 1923. With its inspiring view of the Hudson River, the studio offered private and group lessons in ballet and interpretative dance. Rasch’s strict regimen, including body alignment and breathing exercises based on her own European training, set her dancers apart from the typical chorus-line girls who populated the New York stage. The rigorous training program gave Rasch’s dancers the stamina necessary to endure long vaudeville days and nights and, later, filming that required take after take." www.dimitritiomkin.com/biography/albertina-rasch/ These pictures therefore must date from October, 1923 or after.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: A section from a biography of Jeanette Macdonald starting near the bottom of books.google.com/books?id=ojOxCgHZLpUC&pg=PA47&lp... discusses the influence of Rasch on Macdonald, mentioning a location for Rasch's studio in the Steinway Building on West 57th St., but not giving a date. 109-113 West 57th Street is where Steinway Hall (built in 1925) is located. But it would not have had a view of the Hudson and the architecture doesn't match. Presumably Rasch opened her first studio somewhere else, on the West Side of New York City. Although buildings from this vintage are still found on Riverside Drive on the Upper West Side, the midtown area along the Hudson, which would have been closer to the theatre district, looks as though it has been completely torn up and re-developed. books.google.com/books?id=4iL0a2rQzsgC&pg=PA146&l... is a 1931 directory of schools of the theatre arts. It has the Rasch studio at 113 West 57th, but does have other dance studios on Riverside Drive on the Upper West Side. However, a trip between 73rd and 88th using Google's Streetview didn't find this building.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Another site with extensive info on Rasch is songbook1.wordpress.com/pp/fx/features-2-older-2/albertin...

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: The Washington herald., February 22, 1920, Page 7, Image 21 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1920-02-22/ed-... has an ad (B.F. Keith's is in large letters) for a show in which Rasch appears with her "society pupils as coryphees." So she clearly taught before 1923.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: ok, I think I've found it, in the New York Times on October 21, 1923: *** ALBERTINA RASCH Now preparing her Company for her CONCERT TOUR has opened her DANCE STUDIO 344 W. 72d St., New York City. Tel. Endicott 7589 CLASS — PRIVATE LESSON —BALLET INTERPRETIVE—DANCES ARRANGED. New York recitals in the early Spring. We can place pupils when qualifying *** So, the building is still there, the Chatsworth Apartments, built in 1904. It looks like W. 72d St. used to end on a bluff over the Hudson, but it was redesigned into onramps and offramps from Riverside Blvd. and the Henry Hudson parkway. Still pretty nice location, but not the dreamy little corner it once was. If you look up to the very top on Google Street View, there are slanted windows that match the ones in the pictures of the studio rooms. maps.google.com/maps?q=344+w.+72d+street,+ny&ll=40.78... If you have a spare $150 Million, it might still be for sale: online.wsj.com/article/SB10000872396390444318104577587540... And here is an analysis of The Chatsworth, done in connection with its landmark designation: www.landmarkwest.org/maps_and_data/Designation%20Reports/...

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Terrific, artolog, you've got it.  Try zooming in on the street-level railings and those match too.  I must have missed it on my Google maps pass along Riverside Blvd because the front on that side clearly got changed when the streets were re-arranged.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: www.cityrealty.com/nyc/riverside-dr-west-end-ave/chatswor... shows the building without the scaffolding and tarps in the current GoogleStreet View and www.flickr.com/photos/emilio_guerra/4929595790/in/photost... is one of three photos and has a long description of the building that looks to be a section from a 1984 NYCLPC Landmark Designation Report.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content:
Emilio Guerra's report is the same as my last link above.
It's too bad they got rid of the canopies.  They're really nice.
